Now, that's true of coding and the coding class, and of tech people, you know, that group tends to, I don't want to generalize too much, but it tends to be very black and white. It's binary, like coding.

It's a one or a zero. And so, one of the reasons why you see the problem with Mr. Damore and others, is that they don't see gray, they leap to either a one or a zero. Because that's what they do each day. What they do each day is very binary in the digital world.

CARLSON: People like that should not be in charge of all known information in the English language. They have so much power that I wonder, quickly, if you think this can continue. I mean, how long before they become a rival to the U.S. government and they are broken up or nationalized or regulated like a utility?

CLELAND: It's great that you ask that question. Because information is power. We know, you know, power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely. You know, I think it's Burke and Lord Acton told us that. We are probably on the scale of information is power of one being, you know, power and 10 being information power, we're over seven, well on the way to eight with Google. And it's extraordinary.

People can't imagine it, because these numbers are so big. But they literally have organized all the digital accessible information in the world. And I would say, like, you know, 80 or 90 percent of the stuff that can be found, they found it. Nobody else has the other stuff. And so, it is all on their servers.

CARLSON: Yes. It's terrifying. It's terrifying. Scott, thank you for that glimpse into it. I'm going to buy your book. I appreciate it.

We will back in a minute with an update to a story brought to you earlier this hour, the facts have changed on the ground already. That is next. Stay tuned.

CARLSON: Teleprompter. We want to bring you an update on the San Francisco rally that Nancy Pelosi said she wanted canceled because it was white supremacist even though it turns out most of the speakers aren't white. urn:contentItem:5P8C-0DF1-JB20-G3PK-00000-00Tech Companies Crack Down on White Supremacists; Trump Supporters Say Police Steered Them Into Mob of Protesters After Campaign Rally; New Oregon Law Requires Insurers To Cover Abortion At No Cost To The Patient; Are Tech Firms Trying To Silence Free Speech?2017-08-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:20ZLexisNexisTUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT8:00 PM ESTMark Steyn, Harmeet Dhillon, Joey Gibson, Jacques Degraff, Lila Rose, John Carlos Frey, Scott ClelandNEWSDomestic081601cb.260Tech Companies Crack Down on White Supremacists; Trump Supporters Say Police Steered Them Into Mob of Protesters After Campaign Rally; New Oregon Law Requires Insurers To Cover Abortion At No Cost To The Patient; Are Tech Firms Trying To Silence Free Speech?Tucker Carlson

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST: Good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT. The shock of what happened in Charlottesville over the weekend is ringing in the air like a gunshot. People in every side recognized it was awful because it was awful. Absolutely and completely.

The only thing that could make what happened in Charlottesville worse would be if we allow a small number of people in power to make America less tolerant and less free in its aftermath. Let's be honest, we've seen that before. It happened after 9/11. Almost nobody wanted to say so at the time for fear of seeming sympathetic to terrorists but it did. Secret lists, massive government spying on citizens. The Feds rooting around in people's bank accounts for no good reason.

We allowed all of that to happen because we were upset and afraid. Well, this morning there were signs it could be happening again. The Wall Street Journal reported that big tech companies are using their power to silence certain political views. Both Google and web hosting service Go Daddy stopped providing hosting support for Daily Stormer. That is a white supremacist website.

Meanwhile, the hotel website Airbnb announced it will permanently ban white supremacists from using its service to book rooms. PayPal says, it won't let white supremacists group used its payment platform. Nobody on the show was weeping for the Daily Stormer, even mentioning their name probably got us written up by the Southern Poverty Law Center as dangerous alt-right subversive or something. We don't care.

There's a principle at stake here and it is worth defending regardless. We should be very concerned by the prospect of big companies using their power to enforce ideological conformity even when it seems only to affect people we don't like as it does right now. Especially now we should be concerned because support for free expression appears to be fading on the left and especially among young people.

But 2015 Pew Poll found that 40 percent of millennials already believe in restricting speech that they believe is offensive. Those are the people who are going to be running this world very soon. You think they'll think twice before banning websites they don't like? They won't. The Daily Stormer today is fine. But who is it going to be next week or next year, the national right to life, FOXNews.com, Catholic charities? Why wouldn't it be? And why wouldn't Airbnb ban public supporters of Trump from getting rooms.

They support terrorism. Why wouldn't Facebook eliminate all references to, I don't know, pro-life positions. Today's political opponents could very easily become tomorrow's designated Nazis or terrorists. Definitions change. Principles do not change. And that is way it's crucial to keep fighting for them, keep fighting for an open society even if people call you names when you do it.

Now, the First Amendment is America's most famous freedom, the strongest sign that our country is dedicated to the personal liberty of every person here. The fact that this right applies to the most hated members of society isn't a weakness, it's the whole point. It's proof of how robust that right is. Tech companies aren't the government and they're not bound by the same rules as a consequence of that. But that doesn't mean we shouldn't push back and do it loudly.

The biggest tech firms are more powerful than any monopolies in the gilded age and they're far less restrained and far less trustworthy. In some ways, they're more dangerous even than overreaching government, because they're less accountable. They could make this country a place you would not want to live. And they could probably do it quickly and they probably will do it unless they're brought to heel.

Mark Steyn is an author, columnist and an all-around defender of freedom and a good guy who is nice to sit in for this show last week. He joins us now.

Mark, I'm positive that this segment is going to get us both written up by the Southern Poverty Law Center. I'm not defending any of these creepy groups, this nationalist group or anything like that. I'm not a part of them and don't like them.

MARK STEYN, BEST-SELLING AUTHOR: Yes.

CARLSON: But I think that your poll is worth defending, it's essential.

STEYN: Absolutely. Freedom of speech enables you to argue for other freedoms.

CARLSON: Exactly.

STEYN: And that is the point of it. If you don't have freedom of speech, all can you do is, as they do in un-free societies, is blow things up and shoot people. And it is interesting to me, that the less freedom of speech we have, the more we have what we saw over the weekend. We have guys rampaging through the street. It doesn't really matter what side they're on.

The minute you say that you can't book a conference room and hold a debate, you can't have a "You Tube" channel, you can't go on Facebook, then the logic of that tends towards smashing stuff in the street, whether it's toppling statues like the left did, or whether it's camping about with tiki torches like the right did and rambling on about Jews and all the rest of it. That is why I'm --

CARLSON: That is exactly right.

STEYN: This took place in conference centers. And the other point you made, Tucker, which is absolutely needs underlining, is that it always starts off with the Daily Stormer. But it goes further than that. PayPal for example kicked off V-Day.com. V-Day.com has something to do with what happened in Charlottesville, it is a website that is an immigration restrictionist website.

It thinks post 1965 immigration has been largely disastrous for the United States. And you can say that that is a wrong position to hold. But you are doing something very dangerous when you say you cannot hold that position and use the main credit card processing service on the internet. V-Day.com publishes Ann Coulter and Michelle Malkin, who are no strangers to this channel. And so, there is something actually very disturbing when PayPal boots them off what is essentially a monopoly provider.

CARLSON: I had no idea. And that kind of is the point, it's a monopoly provider as is Facebook, as is Google.

STEYN: Right.

CARLSON: These are companies in American history and world history. And so, as a free market conservative for all of my life, I'm now beginning to think, well, wait a second, do they have too much power? Are they stifling speech?

STEYN: I think what you said last night, Tucker, is absolutely right. I don't see why, if the United States government thinks in 1918 -- not 1918, I think it's about ten years before that, 1909, whenever it was.

CARLSON: Right.

STEYN: Standard oil had gotten too big. If standard oil was too big in 1909, yes, what is Google now? And there's a difference. The oil companies, or MGM when they both made movies and owned cinemas, they're basically in the movie business. Standard oil is in the oil business. Google is in the fourth business. When you have someone who is actually in control of ideas who knows the data of just about all seven billion people on the planet, and it is enforcing an ideological straitjacket, that is far more disturbing than if a standard oil or MGM are enforcing ideological straitjackets.

So, I actually think we're moving into a very dark era where "You Tube" and Facebook and Twitter will bounce more and more people off their monopolies. And that will lead to more violence in the street.

CARLSON: I'm afraid you're right. If there were real liberals still stand as there were in the progressive era, they would understand this. But liberals today so-called are on the side of the moguls, on the side of the Facebook people, on the side of Jeff Bezos, have you noticed this?

STEYN: Yes. As recently as 10, 15 years ago they at least would pay lip service to that apocryphal Voltaire quote that they didn't agree with what you said, but they would defend to the death the right to say it.

CARLSON: Right.

STEYN: Now they will be out in the streets defending to the death, they're right not to have to listen to it. Nobody is asking them. I don't want anybody to defend me to the death or Daily Stormer to the death or V- Day.com to the death or any of them. I don't even want to mildly supportive tweet or Facebook post. All I'm saying and you're saying is that when we have monopoly providers, the idea that they can ideologically constrain that content is very, very dangerous.

CARLSON: No, it's terrifying. Thank you, Mark, for explaining that so well. I appreciate it.

STEYN: Thanks a lot, Tucker.

CARLSON: A group of Trump supporters is suing the city of San Jose, California. They're saying the city failed to keep them safe during a Donald Trump rally in 2016. Cops let the situation got out of control letting protesters rob and assault Trump supporters outside the rally.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: This is a country of about 350,000. It has now almost completely eliminated down syndrome birth since the test began in the early 2000. There are similar trends across Europe. A stark contrast --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Well, that was the wrong sound bite. But we'll take you back to the rally, at which one woman found herself pelted with eggs. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: One young woman tried to take them on proudly showing off her Trump shirt. Then it is so scary, she's hit in the face with watermelon and raw eggs.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Oh my God!

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: She finds herself all alone in the corner. The crowd screaming obscenities and no one came to her aid. Not even the cops.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Harmeet Dhillon is a lawyer and a committee woman for the California RNC. She is also representing some of the attendees at that rally who say, they were jeopardized by the police absence. She joins us tonight.

Harmeet, thanks a lot for coming on.

HARMEET DHILLON, ATTORNEY: Thank you, Tucker.

CARLSON: So, give us the account from the point of view of the Trump supporters at this rally. The police didn't protect them?

DHILLON: Yes. So, I was actually there, Tucker, I did the pledge of allegiance at the Savannah, it was a great event in June last year. And then the police actually directed us there. About 250 of them wearing riot gear, to leave the event. And they directed us directly into a full- fledged riot that was taking place outside the event. And did not let people go in a safer route or another route. And so, what happened was, we saw an assault on numerous individuals. We have 17 named plaintiffs in the case including Rachel Casey you saw there on the video.

And the police made one arrest, and the one arrest was when one of these criminals picked up a barricade and threw it at police. They otherwise did nothing to arrest anybody from teenagers who are our clients all the way to people on their 70s. It was an absolute travesty. And so, we filed this civil rights lawsuit against the city of Berkeley and the police there for failing to honor the civil rights of the Trump attendees.

And the civil rights include being able to attend a conservative event and leave without being assaulted and subject to a riot. And so, so far a case is going on. We survived a motion to dismiss. The judge said that there was not qualified immunity at this stage for the city. And so, the city has appealed that to the Ninth Circuit. That's where we are in that case.

CARLSON: So, what you're saying is something, anyone is paying attention, recognizes. There's a theme here. And it seems like, correct me if I'm being a conspiracy nut, that in certain places local politicians decide they don't want to protect people they disagree with and so they don't. Is that what is happening?

DHILLON: It's not a conspiracy, absolutely. So, right after this event where the whole country, like, the video you saw, saw criminals attacking lawful citizens, the mayor of San Jose, Sam Liccardo, tweeted out that it was Donald Trump's fault. And we saw the exact same pattern in Berkeley where I have also filed a civil rights lawsuit against the University of California, Berkeley, where Berkeley police have basically standing orders to not protect people in a riot unless there is imminent death.

And those are the actual orders of the Police Department and the mayor there who is also a liberal and who is a supporter of black, you know, by all means necessary and sympathizer of Black Lives Matter and other groups like that. And you know, what we saw in Charlottesville as well. So, it is a combination of a lack of will or an absolute hostility by the political authorities in these cities coupled by fear of lawsuits.

I mean, the Berkeley case, what happened was the occupy people filed a lawsuit after being arrested in 2014. And the city caved in and agreed with them in a settlement agreement, that in the future they're not going to get into it if you're having a liberal protest there, they're going to let you do what you do. And they're only going to intervene in case somebody is about to be killed.

So, I don't think citizens know that. I don't think your average citizen going about their business, an anti-fa gang comes and starts throwing things and starts swinging bats and poles and breaking into buildings that the police are just going to stand there and watch you and do nothing. But we've seen that time and time again in the last year.

CARLSON: Well, when you politicize law enforcement, that's really the end of civilization. Thanks for fighting back against that. Harmeet Dhillon, thank you.

So, members of Congress are seizing on the events of last weekend to demand a rollback of freedoms in this country. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi not surprisingly is at the forefront of that, just calling on the National Park service to block a scheduled patriot prayer rally in San Francisco. She calls it a white supremacist event that would promote violence.

Joey Gibson would know because he is the rally's organizer and he joins us tonight. So, let's be totally honest with one another, Joey, I'm sure you're going to be denounced as a white supremacist. Everybody seems to be now. Are you a white supremacist and is this rally a white supremacist rally?

JOEY GIBSON, PATRIOT PRAYER: Absolutely not. I'm not white. We have about eight speakers and only one speaker is white. You know, we have a couple of black speakers, Hispanic, we have a transsexual speaker, we have a woman speaker, it's very diverse. You know, it's really just about what is on the inside. You know, what you believe. You know, your heart, your soul has nothing to do with skin color.

CARLSON: So, you're not only not white supremacists, you are not even white. I find hilarious. I'm sorry to laugh because it's so lunatic that the former speaker of the house is calling you and the people you're speaking with white supremacists. Again, when you aren't even white. Why do think she's saying that?

GIBSON: Well, I think she's trying to capitalize. You know? And everyone is picking up the rhetoric right now. I went to Seattle, a city council member said that I was a white supremacist. You know? And so, I think it's frustrating because right now we have these politicians, they believe it's okay to lie. You know, we let them get away with it. She's going to make such a ridiculous lie.

Like even the fact that I'm brown and she's going to say, I'm a white supremacist. And it's really frustrating, you know? And you know what she'd doing, she's making it more dangerous for San Francisco. What she's trying to do is she is trying to rile up the -- her citizens so that they'll come down there and try to chase us out. You know? And she's using that rhetoric. And it is just going to cause more violence and it is going to put people in danger.

CARLSON: Well, that's actually a really good point, and she's announced publicly that your event is a white supremacist event. And I'm sure that there are a lot of organized lunatics who would go no matter what. But probably some people who are legitimately upset by that, they weren't lunatics who saw what happened in Charlottesville, and they're going to come down, too. I mean, this does raise the chance that something awful will happen. Have you complained directly to her, to Nancy Pelosi about this?

GIBSON: We're working on it. The thing is, she doesn't understand that this rhetoric, like, it's just -- she's quadrupled the size of the rally. You know, she's given us publicity but now she's going to quadruple the size of the protesters. And so, I don't know what she's thinking. Like, I don't understand her logic. Because obviously they won't be able to pull it. But I really think that she's just trying to further her own agenda.

You know, she feels like it's okay to lie and to be deceptive. I mean, she has a long history of lying. And I just -- I don't get why San Francisco puts up with that. And the fact that really, she's not caring about her citizens or San Francisco. I mean, look at San Francisco. Look how dirty, look at the trash, look at the garbage. Like she doesn't even take care of her own people. And now she is trying to make this more violent and more dangerous.

So, I don't know what she's thinking. I don't know if she's trying to provoke or she is trying to bring in racists or what. But I'll tell you this much. I can give you my word that we're not going to allow any white supremacists in.

CARLSON: Yes.

GIBSON: We're not going to allow any Nazis in. In fact, our speakers will be very upset, because they're all of color, if we have any Nazis or any white supremacists in there. I mean, how disappointed would you be if you're a white supremacist and you go to a rally and there's only one white person speaking.

CARLSON: It's unbelievable.

(LAUGHTER)

Good luck, Joey, great to see you.

GIBSON: Thank you.

CARLSON: Baltimore hastily tore down four confederate statues -- violence and distraction in Charlottesville and Durham.

Up next, we'll talk to a pastor who says all remaining confederate memorials must be torn down.

Also, Bill Kristol went after this show last night. He declined to come on to explain it but we'll tell what you he said. Stay tuned.

CARLSON: Last night the top of the show, we addressed the removal of civil war monuments from public places around the country. We made the point that the sudden outrage over confederate icons isn't entirely about slavery horrifying as slavery is. It's also part of a larger effort on the left to discredit the founders of this country and the beliefs they enshrined in law. Once you believe that any figure in history who once owned slaves is inherently illegitimate and should be erased, it's hard to take our founding documents very seriously.

How can you accept the bill of rights when it was written by slave owners? Well, you can't. Which is why so many on the left don't. And ignore the first and second amendments among many others. That was the point we were trying to make. You may disagree with it but it didn't seem crazy or mean spirited. Here's the tweet that Bill Kristol, the former Weekly Standard editor and contributor sent minutes later referring to our segment last night.

Quote, "They started by rationalizing Trump. They ended by rationalizing slavery." Rationalizing slavery? That is not even close to what we were saying by any interpretation. What an outrageous thing to say. But it got worse. Just minutes later, Kristol suggested, somehow we were anti-Semitic too. Here's a second tweet. Quote, "Next, Luther, Voltaire and Marx were anti-Jewish. So, why is it a big deal that the marchers were chanting "Jews will not replace us," end quote.

Okay. That is libel but it is also really stupid. And yet, Bill Kristol isn't stupid. I know that because I worked for Bill Kristol for more than five years in the 1990s, I knew him well. He was a genuinely smart guy. He's a good boss, too. He was humane and fair-minded. He was the kind of person I never would imagine would write something that nasty and dishonest about an enemy much less an old friend. What happened?

Well, Kristol refused to explain himself today. We can only guess at that. Part of the explanation has to be the moment that we're living in right now where hysteria has supplanted rational debate. Well, the purpose of political argument is no longer to explain your beliefs but to highlight what a morally upstanding person you are, a virtuous guy you are, using by contrast of your opponent who is by definition evil. It's childish, obviously.

But for many people, it's pretty tempting. Even 64-year-old men with Harvard degrees fall for it, apparently. But part of the problem is also the medium. Twenty years ago when Bill Kristol had something to say, he had a magazine to say it in. He talked through ideas with his friends, then he spent hours writing a piece that expressed its ideas precisely. There was thinking involved in the process.

Now, he just goes on Twitter and stays on Twitter all day every day. Dashing off little thoughts and impressions, scoring tiny little points against strangers in cyberspace, keeping obsessive track of his likes and re-tweets. At an age when he could be playing with his grandchildren, Krystal is glued to social media like a slot machine junkie in Reno. And after a while, of course that distorts you.

When disagree with someone, it doesn't occur to you to pick up the phone and hash it out. You tweet it hoping for re-tweets. It's depressing as hell. Kristol isn't the only one who does this obviously. Washington is littered with formerly impressive people who now to shout and preen on social media. But I hate to see it with him. I liked Bill Kristol once and I thought he liked me. What a shame.

Well, after the weekend, violence in Charlottesville, several cities have decided that they, too, are going to take down their monuments to the civil war. Baltimore hastily carried away four confederate monuments Wednesday morning. Lexington, Kentucky is hoping to do the same.

The Reverend Jacques Degraff is a FOX News contributor. He is a social justice champion, he says. And he supports removing all confederate monuments. Reverend Degraff joins us now. Jacques, good to see you.

REV. JACQUES DEGRAFF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to see you, Tucker.

CARLSON: So, let me just say at the outset that I'm kind of sympathetic to your point of view. I mean, I wouldn't want to see something that offended me every day, if there was an Al Sharpton monument in my street, Marion Berry monument, I wouldn't like it. So, I don't, you know, if you are offended by these monuments, I totally get that. But here's my question.

DEGRAFF: It's not that I'm offended, it's an offense to the United States of America to honor war criminals. To honor those who were traitors.

CARLSON: So, that's the standard. I just want to know what the -- well, they certainly were traitors of our country, they started their own country.

DEGRAFF: So, the combination, there's no country on the planet no, society, that would honor those. People with credentials like that.

CARLSON: Except ours, because it was a civil war. And I agree with your definition. I mean, they were traitors to America. But then they came back into America. They reintegrated into America. That was the point. The country broke. And then it came back, absolutely and thank God they did. But it was a civil war, it wasn't like we were invaded. And so, it's a little bit more complicated than that. But here is my question. Does your view of this apply to all slave holders or just civil war figures?

DEGRAFF: It's not just civil war figures. But civil war confederate heroes and leaders are not to be honored in any shape, manner or form as a societal imperative. And the fact that we're coming to our senses with the statues and with the stars and bars, the American swastika, they all must fall. We thought we had resolved this in Charlotte a couple of years ago. It's still not resolved. And so, we're moving expeditiously in every form and fashion to complete the task over eradicating these symbols of hatred and division. Now, as to slave holders, to say the issue of slave holders.

CARLSON: One thing, just so you know, let me just inform you one thing. And I'm not even arguing with you, I am just saying, one of the reasons this hasn't been resolved is because the public is not for doing this. Only a small minority, only about a quarter of people polled yesterday in the United States thought that these monuments should come down. Over 60 percent said, they should remain as historical remnants of an earlier age. So like, you need to get the public onboard before you do this. Would you agree?

DEGRAFF: Well, the height of the civil rights movement, there were a lot of people that said, you need to go slow, you need to take your time, and now the people who they were saying that to are American heroes. So, sometimes heroes, just like the people in the Boston Tea Party if you had polled Boston, there would have been people who would say, why are you throwing our tea in the harbor? So, sometimes people --

CARLSON: Well, because it wasn't a democracy then. Hold on. It was not a democracy. Hold on! No, no, no, no. So you've given up on the idea of representative government?

DEGRAFF: No, I haven't given up on anything.

CARLSON: Yes, you have.

DEGRAFF: What I'm saying is --

CARLSON: Okay.

DEGRAFF: I understand that some people who champion social justice get it before the main society gets it. Just as some people in the Republican Party were slow to get their president as dysfunctional.

CARLSON: Okay. Yes. Let's get back to the question of slave holders, though. Because I think this isn't meaningful. I think you make a more defensible point on the civil war question. But what bothers me about the idea that all slave holders need to be erased from American history.

DEGRAFF: I think the issue is not being erased from history. It's being - -

CARLSON: What is the issue?

DEGRAFF: -- not celebrated. If you put your name on a building you're being celebrated.

CARLSON: Okay. Well, the city I live in is named after the founder of the country, the first president, whose plantation which was populated by slaves is right down the road at Mount Vernon. So, I mean, this is not a rhetorical question, it's a real question, should we change the name of the capital of the country? What should we do about George Washington?

George Washington is not like a confederate general. George Washington is the founder of a country and put his life on the line in order to do so. He was a flawed human being but he created a great thing. He was part of the great creation that is self-perpetuating and self-correcting. That's what the process is about.

CARLSON: Yes.

DEGRAFF: And so, the fact is, that right now, we can get to George Washington and Washington, D.C. But right now we need to take care of these confederate statues.

CARLSON: Okay. Let me just say, I don't want to get to Washington or Washington, D.C. I don't want to rewrite the history of this country. I like where you left off the first time, he redeemed himself by his good deeds which he did.

Reverend, thanks a lot for joining us. I appreciate it.

DEGRAFF: Thank you for having me.

CARLSON: Oregon has passed a law to give free abortions to everybody including illegal aliens. That's not insane or anything.

Meanwhile, Planned Parenthood wants to teach your five-year-old about transgenderism. Live Action Founder Lila Rose will be here to discuss both. We're not making that up, by the way. So, stay tuned.

CARLSON: Well, the culture of death is on the march across American in the world in case you haven't noticed. In the state of Oregon, the Governor just signed a bill ordering all insurance companies to provide free abortions. Also allocating state funds to ensure illegal aliens can get abortions as well. Because that will make the country better. Meanwhile, a new report from CBS News celebrates Iceland's near elimination of Down Syndrome. How did they pull off that miracle?

By killing any baby who had it through abortion. And a new Planned Parenthood pamphlet argues that children as young as four ought to be told that men can get abortions too because, quote, "your genitals don't make you a boy or a girl." Lila Rose constructed this staff for a living. He is the author and founder of Live Action for life group and she joins us tonight.

So, the Oregon abortion law, you know, no subject is more dishonestly covered by the press than abortion, because 100 percent of people in the press corps support it. So, it's hard to get to know what is in a bill like this. Tell us what this bill says.

LILA ROSE, FOUNDER AND PRESIDENT, LIVE ACTION: Sure. So, Tucker, this is the most extreme state law on abortion that our country has seen. Basically a completely Democratic-held government in Oregon has said that abortions through all nine months, even sex selection abortions, no limit whatsoever are now going to be paid for by taxpayers in Oregon. And insurance companies are going to be forced to fund it. So, this could cost over 3,000 lives, extra lives killed, children killed every year in Oregon because of this extreme pro-abortion agenda held by the government in Oregon.

CARLSON: So, let me, because I'm a simple man, let me ask you a simple question. Sex selection abortions almost always reduce the number of daughters born.

ROSE: Of girls.

CARLSON: They're performed in order to get a son. Always. How can feminists be for that? How can a feminist, you know, sworn to defend women, support a sex selective abortion?

ROSE: It's the height of hypocrisy, and it just shows that how out of touch the so-called champions of many women are in this country. In reality, you have 100 million missing girls worldwide because of sex selection abortions. Search and destroy mission against girls in the womb. And Oregon is now funding it. Forcing taxpayers and insurance companies to fund it, saying for whatever reason, you can have an abortion, through all nine months, Tucker.

Whether you're first trimester baby or your baby about to be born, you can be killed in Oregon. This is because our country has lost sight of what science and reason tells us, which is that life in the womb has human rights just like you or I do.

CARLSON: So, CBS is pretty excited about this great medical advance in Iceland where they somehow eliminated Down Syndrome? Like how did they do that?

ROSE: It was not a medical breakthrough. Iceland has championed the end of Down Syndrome and Australia is talking about this as well, other European countries. They're not actually treating Down Syndrome, Tucker. They are not actually helping people with disabilities. They're killing people with disabilities. They're killing them off. This is genocide. And what message are we telling people with disabilities.

What message does this send to those that have disabilities in our communities? It sends the message that we wish in Iceland or in Australia or even in the United States, Down Syndrome children are targeted for abortion. It sends a message to them that your life doesn't matter, you are not valuable. It is exactly the wrong message to send.

CARLSON: Yes. And there's no evidence at all that Down Syndrome causes suffering for the person who's born with it. I mean, right? There's no -- Down Syndrome, people are people. Happy people, actually.

ROSE: Well, I mean, exactly, Tucker. You know, it's kind of besides the point. Because even if you have a disability and you have suffering, your life still has meaning and you still have the right to life.

CARLSON: Right.

ROSE: So, suffering or no suffering, you're still worth protecting and cherishing. And looking to alleviate suffering instead of looking to kill.

CARLSON: Yes. Lila Rose, thanks for joining us. I appreciate it.

ROSE: Thank you, Tucker.

CARLSON: A documentary filmmaker says, John Kelly getting the chief-of- staff job at the White House could drive militarization on the U.S. border and put the U.S. in a de facto war with Mexico. That filmmaker got back from the border, he join us next.

CARLSON: President Trump recently elevated Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly to the post of chief-of-staff in the White House. Critics of border security say that's not a good thing.

John Carlos Frey, the documentary filmmaker whose works include life and death at the border. In a recent interview with Democracy Now, he warned that Kelly, a former general would help turn the border into a war zone and exacerbate a, quote, "culture of cruelty" in American border enforcement.

John Carlos Frey joins us tonight. John Frey, thanks a lot for coming on. So, what do you mean by this. How will Kelly, as White House chief-of- staff, make the border patrol more militaristic?

JOHN CARLOS FREY, SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT, MARSHALL PROJECT: Well, I'm not sure that I said that Kelly would make such things happen. But what I did say is that, having a militaristic approach at the border is what we've been doing probably since 9/11 and that doesn't seem to be the most effective strategy at least for my reporting. We have unmanned drones that fly over the U.S.Mexico border. Today, we have over 700 miles of border fencing.

We have border patrol agents in the amount of over 20,000, and it seems to be on the increase. So, you know, we're talking about an issue of migration. We're talking about poverty, we're talking about people who are suffering from violence south of the border. A militaristic approach doesn't seem at least from my reporting to be the most effective strategy. Border security is important. But it seems like that's all we're doing. To put a general in charge of the U.S.-Mexico border might have a heavy- handed approach.

CARLSON: Yes, I don't know that he's in charge of that necessarily as chief of staff. But a part of what you said, I agree --

FREY: Well, he was in charge at the Department of Homeland Security. Right. I mean, he was in charge of the Department of Homeland Security.

CARLSON: Now, he's not. Right. So, but I guess my question is, if what we're doing isn't working and demonstrably it's not, and we have 11 or 12 million people here illegally who got over the border, what would work?

FREY: Right. Well, one of the things that we're not taking a look at is the visa system. Almost half of all the people who come to the United States without papers come with an expired visa, overstay their visa, or come into the United States and don't even cross that border. So, you can go ahead and build a border wall from sea to shining sea and build it 20 feet tall. But people who come into the country legally, won't even cross that barrier.

So, we're not even taking a look at revamping the border system. We're also importing workers in the United States. What about all of the employers here in the United States? Agriculture, and hospitality, restaurants, I'm sure if you go to dinner tonight in Manhattan, there will be undocumented people working in the kitchens. So, what about the employers who don't seem to be going after that?

CARLSON: So, let me ask you a question though. You're right. Sure. But when, I think that is a fair point. We are not going after them. But when did liberals become so sympathetic to employers in search of cheap labor? I don't remember that as a teacher of American liberalism when I was a kid. Like I interview these people all the time who say, you know, you can't be against illegal immigration, because illegals made your dinner tonight. And they never say, well, wait a second, maybe they made my dinner because employers want to pay their workers less. And this isn't an easy group of people to exploit. I would think liberals would be very against illegal immigration.

FREY: I'm at least for my reporting, I'm not necessarily, you know, this isn't for me, this isn't the Republican, Democrat, or liberal or conservative issue here.

CARLSON: Right.

FREY: We're talking about a country that borders the United States, that is poor for the most part, where governments are corrupt, if you go to Central America. And people are looking for a better life. That's migration. That's what we have. So, if all we do is we throw arms and border walls and unmanned drones at this issue, we're not dealing with the root cause which is the disparity between the two countries. My reporting is pretty clear in taking a look at why people come here. And those are the root causes that sort of bombastic rhetoric doesn't even seem to address. We're not going to solve the problem with the border wall.

CARLSON: No, I think you're right. No, but we're fixing that. We're fixing that. Because thanks to immigration, parts of California are every bit as poor as parts of Mexico now. And so there's less of a disparity. I mean, parts of California really are like Mexico. So, that will help solve it, don't you think?

FREY: Well, go a little further, Tucker. I mean, California provides about 80 percent of all of the produce for the rest of the nation. And who is harvesting that?

CARLSON: That is right.

FREY: So, we're all benefitting from the benefits of illegal immigration. Yes, what we're doing is building a border wall. All you're going to do is make it harder for people to come --

(LAUGHTER)

CARLSON: I knew you were going to --

FREY: What?

CARLSON: I knew you were going to defend employers exploiting cheap labor at that point.

FREY: No, no, no. I'm not defending employers at all. I mean --

CARLSON: Yes, you are.

FREY: Agri-business is benefitting. No, no, sir. I mean, why doesn't the administration take a look at the employers themselves? Why don't we go and take a look at the agri-business?

CARLSON: I agree, amen, now we're on the same page.

FREY: All right. But where is that rhetoric, right?

CARLSON: No, I agree. I mean, look, John, we're out of time but I am affirming you on that point, I agree with you 100 percent.

FREY: All right.

CARLSON: We should do that immediately.

Thanks for coming on tonight, I appreciate it. How much power does Google have and how often are they abusing it?

Up next, we'll talk to men who literally wrote the book on the question, his conclusion you cannot trust Google. And they say, don't be evil. Huh! You should laugh. Stay tuned.

CARLSON: Welcome back. We talked a lot about Google this week. We pointed out the danger of powerful tech companies. And our basic freedoms as exemplified by the fired Google engineer James Damore.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAMES DAMORE, FIRED GOOGLE ENGINEER: There are current dogmas that you really can't defend against at Google. And one of them being that there's any difference between people. They just, the entire time, either just called me names, shamed me, or just made broad generalizations saying that what I was saying was pseudo-Science. When, really, this is scientific consensus.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Our next guest is an expert on the dangers of Google. Scott Cleland is the author of "Search and Destroy: You Can't Trust Google Inc." Probably not a more straightforward book title ever. He runs the Watchdog site Google Monitor which you can still find via Google for now anyway. Scott joins us tonight.

So, you can't trust Google. This is something you've been on to for a while. The rest of us kind of stupidly believed the don't be evil propaganda. To what extent is Google driven by political ideology.

SCOTT CLELAND, PUBLISHER OF GOOGLE MONITOR: They're an exceptionally political company. And it just pervades everything they do. And you know, I think they're Utopians. You know, tech Utopians who believe that, you know, it would be best if we had all information and all power centralized with a philosopher king as we know in history, where you know, one person or group of people, the elites, know what's best. And they subscribe to that kind of tech Utopian political outlook. And they have led their business in that direction. And succeeded in creating unimaginable information power.

CARLSON: They're not liberals in the traditional sense in that they don't believe that you should be able to talk, too. I mean, there's an authoritarian streak obviously. We saw it in the firing of their software engineer. Do they enforce conformity in their business?

CLELAND: Well, a lot of people don't join that don't fit to begin with. So, what you're talking about, is a mono culture. That is very much a tech mono culture, which leans libertarian on some sides but very liberal on the other. But, you know, it is very, very political. Where if you do not agree, you don't fit in. Now, that's true of coding and the coding class, and of tech people, you know, that group tends to, I don't want to generalize too much, but it tends to be very black and white. It's binary, like coding.

It's a one or a zero. And so, one of the reasons why you see the problem with Mr. Damore and others, is that they don't see gray, they leap to either a one or a zero. Because that's what they do each day. What they do each day is very binary in the digital world.

CARLSON: People like that should not be in charge of all known information in the English language. They have so much power that I wonder, quickly, if you think this can continue. I mean, how long before they become a rival to the U.S. government and they are broken up or nationalized or regulated like a utility?

CLELAND: It's great that you ask that question. Because information is power. We know, you know, power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely. You know, I think it's Burke and Lord Acton told us that. We are probably on the scale of information is power of one being, you know, power and 10 being information power, we're over seven, well on the way to eight with Google. And it's extraordinary.

People can't imagine it, because these numbers are so big. But they literally have organized all the digital accessible information in the world. And I would say, like, you know, 80 or 90 percent of the stuff that can be found, they found it. Nobody else has the other stuff. And so, it is all on their servers.

CARLSON: Yes. It's terrifying. It's terrifying. Scott, thank you for that glimpse into it. I'm going to buy your book. I appreciate it.

We will back in a minute with an update to a story brought to you earlier this hour, the facts have changed on the ground already. That is next. Stay tuned.

CARLSON: Teleprompter. We want to bring you an update on the San Francisco rally that Nancy Pelosi said she wanted canceled because it was white supremacist even though it turns out most of the speakers aren't white. Well, since the show started the Bay Area Park Services reacted to our interview, we'll take credit of course for this.

Their statement is this, from the head of the Park Service, they take very seriously the concerns expressed by the public and elected officials regarding the rally but they must be guided they say, by quote, "the constitution, the law, and long-standing court precedent." The final decision will be made in the next seven days, hopefully Nancy Pelosi will not be able to bully them out of their right to assemble.

That's it for us tonight, "THE FIVE" starts right now. We'll see you tomorrow.

Alphabet, Apple and Amazon are cutting profitability, while Facebook and Microsoft are raising profits. The 'Big Tech' enters by 15% more in full increase in regulatory pressure.
Three of the big U.S. tech makers, Apple, Alphabet and Amazon, have seen their net profit fall in the third quarter, thus slightly reducing the aggregate profitability of American Big Tech, a group that also includes Microsoft and Facebook. These five companies, the largest North American technology by capitalization, total quarterly profits of $39,657 million (35,544 million euros), a 1% less year-on-year. Its aggregate sales amount to $225.227 billion, up 15 percent.


These disparate results come at a time marked by increased regulatory pressure in the United States on these digital giants, especially Google and Facebook, investigated for their possible anti-competitive practices.
Both Amazon and Alphabet have defended the increase in spending as a weapon to ensure long-term growth before investors, even if they have to pay the price for a quarterly profit reduction. The e-commerce giant has seen its profits fall for the first time nearly two years - it fell by 26%, to $2.13 billion - after its operating expenses to 25 percent of its operating expenses to $41.302 billion. A rate above 23% growth in revenue, which was $70 billion.
Free deliveries
This increase is largely explained by the deployment in the United States of free deliveries in 24 hours for its subscribers, a program costing $2.3 billion in the second half. Amazon is confident that this aggressive ultra-fast delivery policy will raise average spending per customer. In the third quarter, online sales increased by 22%, while total revenue grew by 24%, to $70 billion.
In the case of Alphabet, Google's parent company, the growth in operating expenses - 25% more year-on-year to a record historic $31.3 billion - is attributed, above all, to a greater investment in the data centers it requires to operate the business.
Expenses have also been impacted by increased research staffing, rising content production costs, and the payment of delayed taxes in France. In addition to skyrocketing operating expenses, the $1.53 billion devaluation of its investments in other companies has contributed to a 23% quarterly net profit decline to just over $7 billion. Turnover was boosted by 20%, to $40.5 billion.
Apple Diversifies
Among the companies that have reduced profit also includes Apple, whose quarterly net profits fell by 3% to $13,686 million. However, investors were more concerned about whether the company was progressing in its diversification strategy to rely less on the iPhone, which continues to fall in sales, specifically 9% in the quarter, to $33.362 billion. The growth of 18% of services and 54% of wearables and accessories has allowed Apple to close in positive stake despite the iPhone. Technology increased revenue s just under 2 percent to $64.04 billion, and offered good forecasts for this quarter, to Wall Street relief.
In a quarter of lights and shadows, Facebook continues to demonstrate its growth capacity and profitability, despite its many open fronts, including the increased regulatory pressure that also affects Google. The social network raised 29% of its revenue, to 17,650million dollars, while its net profit increased by 19%, to $6.1 billion. Its results reflect its solid growth in users. The company has 1.6290 million active users, up 9%.
Microsoft and the Cloud
Microsoft, the largest capitalization company, captures the fruits of its commitment to cloud computing, whose business has almost doubled in the last two years. Precisely, the company just won a $10 billion megacontract with the Pentagon this month.
In the quarter ended September, revenue from Microsoft's cloud business soared 36% year-on-year, to $11.6 billion. Your Azure public cloud drive grew by 59% - it doesn't reveal a billing figure - denoting a slowdown when compared to the 76% increase in the same period a year ago and 64% from the previous quarter. Subscriptions to your Office 365 productivity suite, Microsoft's other big cloud business, rose 25%.

urn:contentItem:5J94-PJP1-F03R-N4SG-00000-00Tech companies don't have a clear answer when it comes to data privacy for the Internet of Things2016-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:20ZLexisNexisTech companies don't have a clear answer when it comes to data privacy for the Internet of ThingsAaron Sankin

Mar 13, 2016( The Daily Dot: http://www.dailydot.com/ Delivered by Newstex) If you regularly use a computer or smartphone to access the Internet, which is probable considering you're reading this right now, there are likely no organizations on the planet that know more about you than Google[1], Facebook[2], and Microsoft[3]. As the people in charge of the privacy at those three tech giants gathered onstage during a panel at the South By Southwest[4] Interactive conference in Austin, Texas on Saturday morning the question that, in many ways, dominated the discussion was how to manage users' understandings and expectations about privacy when everything is connected to the Internet—not just computers and smartphones.The panel, which was entitled 'How the Big Tech Firms Protect Consumer Privacy' and hosted by International Association of Privacy Professionals President Trevor Hughes, brought together Facebook Chief Privacy Officer Erin Egan, Google Legal Privacy Director Keith Enright, and Microsoft Chief Privacy Counsel Mike Hintze for a conversation about how the trio of firms deal with privacy issues both in terms of government regulations and in maintaining the trust of their users.'One of the things that makes privacy interesting is that the law is evolving and the technology is evolving, so they questions are constantly evolving,' said Hintze. As a result, when tech companies look at the privacy implications of a new product or feature, the question is often less about whether or not it runs afoul of the current patchwork of government regulations than it is about the perceptions of the consumers using the product.

'Would people be surprised about the data being collected by a product?' Hintze asked. 'Would they be unhappy by not being able to turn it off?'The panel agreed that the best way to accomplish this is by thinking about privacy from the very earliest stages the development cycle. For example, Egan recounted how Facebook brought in privacy experts from academia and the nonprofit sector for looking at the privacy implications of a feature the social network implemented last year that alerts when their friends are nearby. The company was understandably concerned about backlash from users having their locations reported to people they know on Facebook without their explicit consent. The experts advised Facebook represent the geolocation feature picture of a phone in a pocket as a visual companion to the text notification. 'Consent is a core aspect of privacy.' Egan insisted. 'Consent can be really good too, if it's in context. The question is what does it mean and how do we present it in a way so people understand it?However, getting user consent on how information is used has issues of its own. The nuts and bots of how Facebok uses the data of its over one billion users is tucked away in the depths of its lengthy agreement. The company has implemented a simple interface where users can do privacy check-ups to manage what information they share and with whom, but those efforts haven't seemed to engender a significant level of faith among the public at large. According the recent survey[5] of nearly 2,000 registered voters conducted by Morning Consult, only 32 percent respondents had 'total' confidence in Facebook's ability to keep their personal information and data secure. Facebook isn't exactly alone in having a user trust problem. The survey found that much of the tech industry is facing a crisis of confidence when it comes to the responsible use and storage of user data. The segment of users that place trust in each company stands at 50 percent for Google and 54 percent for Apple[6]. For Uber, the figure was an abysmally low 18 percent. Not a single organization the pollsters asked about cracked 60 percent. What's interesting here is that a lack of confidence in data security isn't stopping people from using these services. Uber, which was the least trusted of all the companies queried about, still delivers over two million rides per day[7]. Nevertheless, likely as a result of uncertainly, people are worried about what companies are doing with their data, which is precisely why the panelists emphasized that informing the public what happens to their information is so crucial. 'To a degree that we're engaging with a user on a screen, even if its a small screen on a phone, we're getting better and better on giving people ways to meaningfully give consent,' noted Enright, adding one major caveat.'In some respects we're solving yesterday's problems,' he continued. 'All of that work doesn't necessarily move the ball forward on solving tomorrow's problem when we're living in a world of connected cars and thermostats. It's going to have to be more of a focus on user education ... We are necessarily going to be moving away from the paradigm we have now with keyboards and screens.'As much of the technology on display at the conference indicates, the industry is rapidly moving into a world where the only window into the Internet is through a laptop or smartphone screen. The number of connected devices that comprise the so-called Internet of Things[8] is expected to grow to 38 billion individual units by 2020[9] generating an unimaginably vast and precise amount of data about every aspect of our lives. Informing users exactly where their privacy ends and how their data is used is going to become even more difficult.Take, for example, an Internet of Things light switch installed in a person's house. What's the responsible way to inform people about how the data from that light switch is used? If it's deep in a user manual that comes with the device, the odds anyone will thoroughly read and understand it is essentially zero. It could be put on the device itself, but what if that light switch doesn't come with a display panel or that panel isn't set up to easily display a lot of text?In that case, the issue of consent isn't just dictated by whether the manufacturer places a bold privacy alert on its website, but also by the very nature of the device itself.Hintze suggested a solution of drawing a line between what is being done with the data as to determine if a privacy notification is necessary. 'If the data is anonymous and aggregated, the privacy issue maybe isn't that big an issue,' he said. 'But if the data is connected to an individual, that could be a problem.'He added that, in the latter instance, there's likely to be a sign-up process that does involve a traditional screen. At that point, the user can, at least in theory, be presented with information about, or even given agency to pro-actively change, precisely what information they share. But what happens when there is no screen anywhere in the process? Is it better to just assume that consumers will value the convenience and utility offered by their products over any concerns about privacy and bury data use policies somewhere in the dark recesses of their corporate website? Or is it the obligation of companies to build privacy notification and accessibility into the very design of the product?'I think that ethics is the next big issue in the privacy space,' said Hintze. 'It's not just what can you do. urn:contentItem:5Y49-YCC1-JBG7-40GG-00000-00Tech companies ease into banking as another way to gather data2020-02-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:20ZLexisNexis BUSINESS ZONE CPg. 1Tech companies ease into banking as another way to gather data

Success: Your Monday guide to managing money, work and the business of life

By Kaitlin Pitsker, Kiplinger

Daniel Latimore, a senior vice president for banking at research and consulting firm Celent, discusses banking and financial services.

Q: Why are Apple, Google, Facebook and other tech companies interested in offering banking and financial services?

A: It's not that banking is where the money is, but rather that banking is where the data is. Big tech has grown by monetizing data. By offering a checking account, credit card or other financial product, these companies can gather specific and detailed information about your income, spending, cash flow and other financial habits.

Q: Are the tech firms really becoming banks?

A: For now, they are wading into specific parts of financial services and generally partnering with existing financial institutions. For example, Google will soon offer checking accounts in partnership with Citigroup and Stanford Federal Credit Union. Often, the tech company will be the brand that the customer sees while the bank takes on regulatory issues and other behind-the-scenes tasks. In time, some tech companies may move further into financial services but will likely stop short of crossing lines that require them to deal with regulatory complexity and compliance.

Q: What are the potential benefits for consumers?

A: Tech companies will likely offer lower fees and higher interest rates than traditional banks. Some may offer cash incentives or other perks to encourage customers to make the switch. Many are also focused on offering a better customer experience by offering apps that are easy to use, making it easier to find the information you need within an app, and figuring out the right way and time to connect with you to be useful but not annoying.

As these companies get to know customers better, they'll start giving them personalized offers. For example, if they know how much you're paying on a mortgage, they may infer the rate and offer you a refinance option with a lower rate through a partner.

Q: What are the trade-offs?

A: You are giving the tech company your financial data. They'll see how much money you have in your account, what bills you're paying and more, and they'll use that information to try to sell you stuff and market financial products. Customers who are concerned about their privacy may want to use a diverse portfolio of service providers -- keeping social accounts in one bucket, banking in another and investments in a third -- to avoid giving a single company a full view of their affairs.

Q: Will people make the switch?

A: Inertia is the most powerful force in consumer finance. Getting people to change, unless there's a big shock, is tough. If you want to give the new accounts a try, consider opening one as a secondary account. Over time, you might receive offers that would save you money and you might not mind how your data is being used. ct20 0004 200203 N S 0000000000 00003796

By offering a checking account, credit card or other financial product, these companies can gather specific and detailed information about your income, spending, cash flow and other financial habits.

A: For now, they are wading into specific parts of financial services and generally partnering with existing financial institutions. For example, Google will soon offer checking accounts in partnership with Citigroup and Stanford Federal Credit Union. Often, the tech company will be the brand that the customer sees while the bank takes on regulatory issues and other behind-the-scenes tasks. In time, some tech companies may move further into financial services but will likely stop short of crossing lines that require them to deal with regulatory complexity and compliance.

Q: What are the potential benefits for consumers?

A: Tech companies will likely offer lower fees and higher interest rates than traditional banks. Some may offer cash incentives or other perks to encourage customers to make the switch. Many are also focused on offering a better customer experience by offering apps that are easy to use, making it easier to find the information you need within an app, and figuring out the right way and time to connect with you to be useful but not annoying.

As these companies get to know customers better, they'll start giving them personalized offers. For example, if they know how much you're paying on a mortgage, they may infer the rate and offer you a refinance option with a lower rate through a partner.

Q: What are the trade-offs?

A: You are giving the tech company your financial data. They'll see how much money you have in your account, what bills you're paying and more, and they'll use that information to try to sell you stuff and market financial products. Customers who are concerned about their privacy may want to use a diverse portfolio of service providers - keeping social accounts in one bucket, banking in another and investments in a third - to avoid giving a single company a full view of their affairs. There are also a lot of boring but important functions that traditional banks do well, such as maintaining branch locations and call centers, that aren't always a strong suit for technology companies.

Q: Will people make the switch?

A: Inertia is the most powerful force in consumer finance. Getting people to change, unless there's a big shock, is tough. If you want to give the new accounts a try, you might consider opening one as a secondary account. If over time you receive offers that would save you money and you don't mind how your data is being used, you might consider making it your primary account.

Kaitlin Pitsker is an associate editor at Kiplinger's Personal Finance magazine. Send your questions and comments to moneypower@kiplinger.com

Germany’s government has proposed a clampdown on anti-competitive behaviour by digital platforms, putting Berlin in the vanguard of European efforts to regulate companies including Google and Amazon.

The draft “digital law” will strengthen the intervention powers of Germany’s competition watchdog, the Federal Cartel Office. Peter Altmaier, the economy minister, said the measures would “toughen control of abusive practices for big market-dominating digital companies”.

“There is no other jurisdiction that has proposed such a far-reaching tool for taming the digital giants,” said Rupprecht Podszun, head of the Institute for Competition Law at the Heinrich Heine University in Düsseldorf.

Germany’s bill is part of a broader “techlash” as governments consider ways to limit the economic and social power of the tech giants and public disquiet grows about the potential threats they pose to competition, privacy and civil liberties.

The bill would make it easier for the cartel office to establish whether companies dominate a particular market. The agency would then be able to prohibit such platforms from “self-preferencing” — that is, giving preferential treatment to their own products or services to the detriment of those provided by rivals.

Platforms would also be banned from impeding “data portability”, the ability of users to transfer personal information collected by digital companies to other online services.

The bill, which could still be changed before it is passed into law, also stipulates that a platform can be found to have engaged in “abusive” behaviour if it denies other companies access to the data it has collected on them.

Mr Podszun said this part of the bill “is completely new, and you might say, revolutionary”. He said its practical impact might not be great, “but the signalling effect is huge”. He added: “You could see France and Italy following suit, and the net gradually tightening.”

Daniela Seeliger, a partner at Linklaters who specialises in competition law, said: “Germany is taking a first step and putting into concrete proposals what other countries are thinking about in more abstract terms.” She said the EU could go down the same route.

The German bill comes as Brussels also considers moves to toughen regulation. EU competition commissioner Margrethe Vestager recently called for the burden of proof in antitrust cases to be placed on the big tech companies themselves.

Meanwhile the UK government is making plans for a  regulator to police the technology sector. The idea reflects the findings of a review led by Jason Furman, chief economic adviser to former US president Barack Obama, which looked into the “emergence of powerful new companies” in the tech sector and recommended a dedicated regulator.

Andreas Mundt, head of the German cartel office, told the FT late last year that the proposed digital bill was part of a broader trend that also included the Furman report and recent moves to clamp down on big tech companies in Australia.

“What is happening in Germany is very much embedded in my understanding of the international context, based on many studies around the world that go in the same direction,” he said.

His agency has already earned a reputation for its robust stance towards Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple. A year ago it blocked Facebook from pooling data collected from Instagram, its other subsidiaries and third-party websites without user consent. The decision was later overturned by a court in Düsseldorf, although the cartel office has since appealed.

The draft digital law has drawn a sceptical response from German business. Iris Plöger of the BDI, the main German business lobby, said it “would make it difficult to create internationally competitive digital companies”. She said it would also widen the gap between German and European law.

Rebekka Weiss, of the digital lobby group Bitkom, said the bill was “so unclear in some of its formulations that it could have negative consequences for new emerging business models that the law is expressly designed to support”.
